contextId.information: Here "hands" refers to the people of Jabesh Gilead. AT: "be strong" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

David is stating the condition under which he will meet Abner. Here "face" refers to David himself. AT: "you cannot see me unless you bring Michal to me first" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: you cannot see my face unless you first bring Michal

contextId.information: In this phrase "his hands" represents Ishbosheth. AT: "Ishbosheth became weak" or "Ishbosheth lost all strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here David represents his soldiers. AT: "David and his soldiers attacked" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "he" refers to David who represents his soldiers. AT: "Then they defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here both "David" and "Hadadezer" represent their armies. AT: "David and his army then defeated the army of Hadadezer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here David represents his soldiers. AT: "David and his soldiers killed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here David represents his soldiers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "David" represents his army. AT: "David's army had defeated" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here "me" refers to Joab who represents his soldiers. Also, Abishai represents his soldiers. AT: "for us, then you, Abishai, and your army must rescue us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: for me, then you, Abishai, must rescue me

contextId.information: Here Abishai represents his soldiers. AT: "from Abishai and his soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here David represents his soldiers. AT: "against David and his soldiers and fought them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The phrase "the hand of Uriah" refers to Uriah himself. AT: "sent Uriah himself to deliver it to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: sent it by the hand of Uriah

contextId.information: The servants are referred to here by their voices to emphasize that they were speaking. AT: "he did not listen to us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: he did not listen to our voice

contextId.information: Here the author says "Joab" but he is referring to Joab and his soldiers who fought with him. AT: "Joab and his soldiers fought ... they captured" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here Joab speaks of himself when he is actually referring to himself and his soldiers. AT: "My soldiers and I have fought ... my soldier and I have taken ... if my soldiers and I take" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: I have fought ... I have taken ... if I take

contextId.information: Here the author speaks of David when he is actually referring to David and his soldiers. AT: "David and his soldiers fought" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This does not include Absalom and Amnon who is dead. It includes the rest of the sons that the king allowed to go to the celebration. AT: "the rest of the king's sons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here David is referred to by his mind to emphasize his thoughts. AT: "King David longed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The mind of King David longed

contextId.information: Here the word "face" refers to the king himself. AT: "but he may not see me ... the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: but he may not see my face ... the king's face

contextId.information: Here "the king's face" refers to the king himself. AT: "the king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here the men are referred to by their "hearts" to emphasize their loyalty to Absalom. AT: "The men of Israel are loyal to" or "The men of Israel are following after" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: The hearts of the men of Israel are following after

contextId.information: Here David speaks of Absalom and the men with him as "Absalom" himself because the men are following Absalom's authority. AT: "escape from Absalom and his men ... he and his men will quickly ... and they will bring" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: escape from Absalom ... he will quickly ... and he will bring

contextId.information: Here "hand" refers to control. AT: "into the control of Absalom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to Israel's soldiers, not to all of Israel. AT: "then all of our soldiers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This refers to both the armor he would wear to protect himself and to his weapons. AT: "armor and weapons" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here the soldiers are referred to by their face to emphasize how they would have hid their faces because of their shame" AT: "You have caused all your soldiers to hide their faces in shame today" or "You have caused all of your soldiers to be ashamed today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: You have shamed the faces of all your soldiers today

contextId.information: Here "hand" means control. AT: "from under the control of our enemies" or "from our enemies' control" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: out of the hand of our enemies

contextId.information: Here "Sheba" refers to both him and his army. AT: "Sheba and his army" or "Sheba and his men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The word "day" represents the span of time when David was in distress. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Yahweh has put David in a safe place where his enemies cannot trap him. "Feet" refers to David's ability to stand securely. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: You have made a wide place for my feet beneath me

contextId.information: This phrase represents the king's command to them. AT: "what the king had commanded" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
